\begin{document}

\title{Notes on the SMEFT implementation}

The standard gluon-to-gluon splitting function at LO reads:
\begin{equation}
P_{gg}(x) = 4C_A\left[\frac{1}{(1-x)_+}+\frac{1}{x}-2+x-x^2\right]+\frac{11C_A-4N_f T_R}{3}\delta(1-x)
\end{equation}
where we have used our definition of the expantion parameter
$\alpha_s/4\pi$. Using the SMEFT approach the same splitting function
gets an additional contribution:
\begin{equation}
P_{gg}(x) \rightarrow P_{gg}(x) + \Delta P_{gg}(x,\mu)\,,
\end{equation}
where:
\begin{equation}\label{DeltaP}
\Delta P_{gg}(x,\mu) = -\frac{4C_A}{g_s(\mu)}\left[\frac{1}{(1-x)_+}+\frac{1}{x}-2+\delta(1-x)\right]\frac{C_G}{\Lambda^2}\mu^2\,.
\end{equation}
In eq.~(\ref{DeltaP}) the ratio $C_G/\Lambda^2$ is a fixed parameter
while $g_s(\mu) = \sqrt{4\pi \alpha_s(\mu)}$. In addition, the factor
$\mu^2$ that appears in eq.~(\ref{DeltaP}) can be related to $\alpha_s$
by inverting the function $\alpha_s(\mu)$ such that $\mu^2\equiv
\mu^2(\alpha_s)$. Finally, we can write:
\begin{equation}
\Delta P_{gg}(x,\mu) = -\frac{\mu^2(\alpha_s)}{\sqrt{4\pi
    \alpha_s}}4C_A\left[\frac{1}{(1-x)_+}+\frac{1}{x}-2+\delta(1-x)\right]\underbrace{\frac{C_G}{\Lambda^2}}_{K_{\rm EFT}}\,,
\end{equation}
so that:
\begin{equation}
\frac{\alpha_s}{4\pi} P_{gg}(x,\mu) \rightarrow \frac{\alpha_s}{4\pi} P_{gg}(x,\mu) -\sqrt{\frac{\alpha_s}{4\pi}}\frac{\mu^2(\alpha_s)}{4\pi}4C_A\left[\frac{1}{(1-x)_+}+\frac{1}{x}-2+\delta(1-x)\right]K_{\rm EFT}
\end{equation}



\end{document}
